item.title: JRP Roleplay
item.description: ![[assets/images/jrp/Goodbye-Staff-Pic.jpg]] It is with a heavy heart that we are announcing the indefinite closure of JRP Roleplay. With the TES3MP community dwindling down and many of our players having moved on, we feel it is time to offer some closure.

item.title: On The Honors Of The Dead, I
item.description: I, Vadyne Andoril, have served as an inquisitor of the sacred ordination in Necrom for over a century and a half as of the writing of this manuscript.

item.title: On The Honors Of The Dead, II
item.description: “Death does not diminish.” Unlike the outlanders, our dead are not lost to us, to be contacted only by the work of esoteric wizards and warlocks studying the necromantic arts, for grief is powerful in inclining souls to evil.

item.title: On The Honors Of The Dead, III
item.description: “The ghost gilds with glory.” The spirits of the dead become the glory of their house, and the honor of their house falls on them.

item.title: On The Honors Of The Dead, IV
item.description: Some outlanders would have such disrespect for our ancestors that they would ask, “Why should we care about the honor of your kin?

item.title: On The Honors Of The Dead, V
item.description: “I am not of the slaves that perish.” Such were the words of Nerevar the Hortator when he fought the craters of Masser to reach heaven by violence, as Vivec recounts in his sixteenth lesson.

item.title: On The Honors Of The Dead, VI
item.description: Some would make of these words an open invitation to the study of sorcerous necromancy, but such is not my intent.

item.title: On The Honors Of The Dead, VII
item.description: A second danger of sorcerous necromancy is more subtle and known only to the wicked partakers of that art and those like myself who are dedicated to the thwarting of them, that is, the temptation of the wicked beings that call themselves the Ideal Masters.

item.title: The Matter of Aeyet
item.description: A knight, he was learned He was called Talarii and he was from Pelagiad. He wrote this story as poetry. Aayet cried for ten days and ten nights, for without her love she was left in a stun.

item.title: The Matter of Morrowind
item.description: A knight, he was learned and read in books, so that if he with his time could begin nothing better,

item.title: The Matter of Morrowind
item.description: A knight, he was learned He was called Talarii and he was from Pelagiad. He wrote this story as poetry.
